Dynamic Queue is boosting. The terms are interchangeable.

I play with people that I have 0-40% win rates with. I'm pretty sure that's not boosting. If anything, it's lowering my elo. Most of my wins are actually me going into solo games and stomping face with some randoms that see my match history of mostly wins, or my level 7 masteries, or my overall performance with my champions and know they have a good player on their team. It's surprising how effective just having your team know someone on their team is good can get you places.

Riot is implementing this because players like me have no incentive to always play solo. It either feels unfair, or downright has odds stacked against us. Now with this, and hopefully future changes to load screen and things like ward skins (or less excitingly; summoner icons,) we can flaunt that we got to our rank through our own skill. Leading back to what I said above, showing your team: "Hey, I'm a good player. You don't have to worry about me. I can get your back." Dynamic Queue was a step to make Ranked a more enjoyable setting for low elo players who have no care to become high elo imo. Or even new players getting into Ranked. But for players who want the challenge, the intensity of being good at the game; Solo Queueing just helps you know you're good. But without something like this, there was no incentive to climb solo.

Not at all. Playing ranked with people you can trust not to feed is a huge step down from boosting. Not to mention the fact that logically, one in three of the people who are dynamic queuing with these so-called "bad players" must be a better than average player.

It's not boosting if you're playing with people around the same skill level as you. It IS boosting if you're playing with someone who is far better than you who is on their smurf and playing Dynamic with you.

Only if you queue with people higher elo than you. If you think five bronze five players getting together is boosting you're a special kind of stupid. Bit I'm sure you aren't that stupid because nobody is right.

I think Riot's genuinely trying to find a solution, and I appreciate that.
However, it worries me that they seem to have such an incredibly poor understanding of the problem.

Riot, I can't claim to speak for everyone, but my perception is that nobody much cares about RECOGNITION, they care about FINDING OUT HOW THEY MEASURE UP TO A COMPETITIVE STANDARD. 
Lumping premades in with the solo players means that that competitive standard loses its integrity - comparing solo performance to premade performance is apples to oranges. The ranks lose meaning because it isn't clear anymore what they're even measuring.

A shiny badge for solo-only players doesn't even begin to address this issue at all. What _might_ be a step in the right direction is if you presented a way for solo players to see their rank relative to only other solo players.

(This is in addition to and aside from frustration towards the perceived unfairness of having solo teammates versus a coordinated premade group in any one particular match, but I think you guys are trying to address that elsewhere.)
